message: yes
downloadable zip? you can already do that!
for hg/django to work flawlessly on top of it
What's that one thing you're aching to have?
Yeah, I've thought about that for a while. Better branch browsing. We don't do that very well right now.
cool, glad people would like that idea :)
you know, I've made a lot of effort into that lately: https://bitbucket.org/jespern/jsudiff/src
also, pages load faster :)
better marketing of the downloadable zip then? :)
what do you need?
this is because I use my browser as a code viewer, so being able to find it with firefox's autobar is big
a timeline per branch
@alex grab the repo I just posted and open test.html
@alex: diffs will soon be highlighted client-side, the speedup we've seen using that is crazy
@alex yep, it's a 1:1 port
@convy fair enough :)
having the default source view use master in the URL, rather than the sha
a wikiindex, so I can find all the pages in a wiki even if they aren't linked
downloadable zip of a project.
@jespern hokey dokey, this probably means someone (you?, me!) should write a pygments benchmark for pypy
So, like, use the names of the branches/tags?
if only we could host bb on pypy..
it'd be nice if wiki pages's history said who made a change
@jespern will it still look as good?
@jespern now i see the download link, I got confused with the downloads tab that says 0.
A github-network-graph-like glog of all the forks of a given repo together.
so thanks for that!
oh restyle the forks page
@jespern why only diffs client side? pygments particularly slow with diffs, or just a starting point?
what pricing model? ;)
glad to hear it :)
I used to be able to do that kind of thing w/ svn hosts like google using autoprops
accessing the raw file would be served text/html so I could host from there
yeah
One of my long time wish-list items landed recently: multiple emails/account
no doubt
The office has finally gone all HG, so BB is a much more frequent topic
:) me too
I'll be interested in your findings
will see how the diffs goes
the problem with that is obviously javascript executing on our domain
integration w/ readthedocs would be cool too
@pmclanahan it was our biggest bottleneck when displaying diffs, which we do a lot of. :)
better support for project/user web pages or sphinx docs hosting
may introduce client-side syntax highlighting too
otherwise I'd love to do that
@jespern also, seeing your jsudiff repo makes me wish it would serve HTML files w/ the proper mime type so the browser would display it
too bad there are people out there that wants to harm us :)
plenty I'm sure
it'd be opening a can of worms
we got way more good stuff coming.
yeah. bummer.
everyone loves the new pricing model :)
is that why you haven't done more w/ the user pages hosting stuff?
glad to see you guys pushing out new features at a good clip recently
we're not using pygments to highlight diffs
@pmclanahan The slowness was more from recalculating the diffs to highlight intra-line differences, not just Pygments.
ah. intresting.
@jespern any chance you could open source your algorithm so we could make a benchmark out of it?

I would like to request that the "overview" page become more useful. I often am browsing around and when I hit a new project I want to know 1.) what is this? 2.) is it active? 3.) Who is it from? 4.) What is the file structure? 5.) are there other branches? 6.) are there more active forks from other users? Right now it's just a big long changelog which is useful but not what I think of as an "overview"
oh shi-, I missed the iframe part of what you suggested
I dunno if we care that rms and 3 other people in the world don't get pretty highlighted diffs
yeah I know.
I'll try to make a benchmark for PyPy out of this
hopefully we cream CPython
the problem was generating the content, not for the browser to render it
wait, what?
https://github.com/alex/django-vcs/blob/master/django_vcs/diff.py
@poswald excellent feedback, ty.
@alex http://paste.pocoo.org/show/189863/
@jespern haha this is straight out of lodgeit
I know because I've copied it myself once
armin's credited in there :)
omg that's bb code! prepare to get sued.
yeah the jsudiff stuff is a direct port of this
I made the jsudiff stuff highlight lazily as well, so it only highlights as it approaches your viewport. we can just spit out raw diffs and not care now. pretty cool stuff.
that's kinda cool
sucks for people with js disabled though
we made the decision to not support those people a while back
or rather, atlassian did.
which I guess is "we" now.
I'm inclined to say no.
you can make it show as many per page as you want, we just default to 15.
should be a less/more link somewhere. :)
well, could you do <noscript><iframe MAH_HTML_PRETY_DIFF /></noscript>
but I'm saying this way you only do it backend if they have noscript
lol
no idea if it's worth it for your audience
nah cause actually providing that markup would make the response generation as slow as it was before
right
you could do <noscript>fetch_over_ajax and then be like WAITAMINUTE
no you can't
cause if they have noscript then they don't have ajax
I know, that's my attempt at a joke
that's why I suggested iframe :)
right, that's a cool idea

Oh... and a more compact/dense view of the changesets would be nice. You can only see 15 or so per page. With git and hg you end up making a lot of small commits and you don't want to have to keep paging through them all. (since you're listening) :-)
ok didn't know that... I still think its not dense enough for my taste.
a way to automatically import/convert a svn repository would be a cool feature
github has this, but I tried to use it to import a repo from google code and it just timeout
how big was the repo you tried to import?
Its not too big I guess
I tried to import django pyodbc: http://code.google.com/p/django-pyodbc/source/checkout
I would really like to have an RSS feed for the issue tracker so I can import items into my org-mode todo list.
@doughellmann hah, that sounds cool.
Seems like repo urls now default to the wiki page with a fall-back to source page. That's a quick win!
I still don't see how to get less or more changesets per page as you said was possible though. :-/
it's possible: https://bitbucket.org/tortoisehg/stable/changesets/tip:105be55e034a/
/me needs to yell at someone tomorrow at the office.
uh. seems the links have been taken out by someone.
@jespern http://orgmode.org/manual/RSS-Feeds.html#RSS-Feeds

One thing I'd really like to see is a ticket aggregator--some place I can go to see all of the tickets in any project that I'm an admin or member of.  I've started my own little project to list the tickets in various projects using the API, but time is not as plentiful as I'd like it to be so I haven't really gotten anywhere with it.

Another thing that would be definitely nice is repository specific ssh keys with ability to define read/write privileges - totally useful for deployment purposes, where you don't want to associate single-use key with your whole account
Top wish would be to be able to fork stuff from any host / any vcs into bitbucket / mercurial without me having to fork, pull or checkout, convert to mercurial, push.
Managing groups/teams. As a growing company, it is a pain to add individuals one at a time, and also ensure it is the correct individual (since the add autocomplete is a global search).
@unsay Done.
@jespern, thank you, good sir.
I'd like something similar to Github's Gist. If BB had that, I could mostly stop using GH for anything personal.
but it probably is
derp

7pm in the lobby @ the hyatt

it's cool if you don't like/want the feature... it's just something I use and like
but for any and all subjects
guess I'll have to do a survey or something. :)
I'm sure you can do some even cooler stuff w/ it than they have.

and sometimes I use their embed JS thing to post code on my blog

no. it's the pyatl thread
never liked that site much... though it has some excellent stuff on it
fair enough
it just makes me go there more than I'd like ;)
a pastebin? :S

I mainly post stuff there I want to keep and potentially edit
got the impression they're not really used for much else than a pastebin
cool. even I don't think it's a huge deal if you don't have something like it
sweet
possibly
nah
does anyone ever clone a gist?
you couldn't just reply to it?
it's nice b/c it'll update there when I edit the gist
I do think that kind of thing's potential has yet to be reached at GH though
well... an editable, versioned, forkable, and cloneable pastebin. yeah.
not sure. I've forked one though.
and I've definitely benefited from the versioning of them
I'm just curious whether it's ever used
I'm happy to keep using it there... I'd just rather everything be on the service I prefer
if not, I won't bother implementing it
It sounds more useful than perhaps it is
yeah... you should definitely not take my word for it :) no idea how much gists are used
yeah me neither.
could be... if so, I agree... not worth the effort
more around organization and search might make for a good "djangosnippets" replacement
it's hard to design something like it when I don't have any idea how people use gists
I'm not saying no; I just need to learn what people actually do with it
I hear ya :)
you're not at PyCon US are ya?
there's something on tomorrow night around 7, I know that
spike in BB usage from Atlanta probably :)
cool
that's not the Scotch BoF is it?
ah.. yeah. cool. sounds fun. Nice of the PyAtl guys to organize that.

models.py

'this'?
I saw you were using an ORM, noticed models.py, opened up requirements.txt, thought to myself "huh, didn't know tornado bundled an ORM", and went to check. mind blown.
minor suggestion: use @classmethod's instead of @staticmethods most of the places, and use the first arg passed as your constructor instead of hardcoding it
one day
this #1 = convore/catching up on feeds
Getting a List of Events from friends on API. Now is only possible from a user: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BBDEV/Events
branch permissions
(catching up with posts from a while back) I'd also love to see a gist-like feature.  Also, being able to grab a list of forks through the API would be awesome.
@Vasil did you see the new "groups" feature?
something similar to organizations in GitHub would be very useful
as I understand I've to create two different users for this
however I'd like to have my own repositories as well as company repositories, so they'd have an url /companyname/projectname instead of /username/projectname
in github I can just switch context between my username and any organization I manage
+ repo urls are /myusername/projectname and /myorganization/projectname

as I understand groups in bitbucket are there so you can easily manage access to repositories for multiple people, however the owner of the repository still stays the user who created it and if I want the user to be my company I've to create a new user
where in github I just switch context between me and my organization
Ah, I see what you mean.  Whereas with BitBucket you'd have to either give your username admin on every project under the organization user, or logout/login?
and of course login/logout all the time
yeah, no I remember seeing that
That's my current understanding too ... and that's what I did for my project.
Right, I see.
which is something I need because we use mercurial for our comercial/closed projects and we recently moved all those to bitbucket
has anyone said reST for the wiki?
@Vasil that's groups 2. something we're looking into now.
excellent, thanks
Comments on commits would be really cool.

Better project overview page. In my projects the first thing I do is change the default project page to be the "Source" tab because it shows the info I want (readme and source to browse immediately). I 'd like these to move to the overview page along with the current  info on the latest commits.
Also some more intelligent way of sorting out what kind of markup is used in the read me file would be nice. I 'd prefer not having filename extensions on my read me files.
Could happen with some kind of setting in the project admin tab.
I would also love to see the list of the repositories I am following sorted by repo name instead of by author.
IMHO it would be nice to have "infinite scrolling" in the newsfeed page, or at least the possibility to browse older entries
I'd love to be able to build a query for Issues that includes a filtering by a date range - both for when the issue was submitted and when it was resolved.
ability to make downloads (for uploaded files) public on a private repository - for example a checkbox in the repo admin - "Uploaded files are private"
@jespern one thing I just realized I really miss: priority/severity for each issue in the issue tracker... :)
Bookmark support,  I know the extension is enabled, just would be nice if you could see then too :)
